history.text: Hello
Hey. So how did you like the movie, The Social Network?
I really enjoyed it. It's a good biopic that doesn't pull punches
what did you think of it?
I totally agree with you. I am a fan of David Fincher films, and he did a really nice job with this one as well. I usually don't enjoy biographical movies.
I love anything that does a deep dive into character's inner workings. He made Mark Zuckerberg out to be a real piece of work.
Classic anti-hero
Yeah definitely. How do you feel about the portrayal of Zuckerburg? Do you think his character is super true to life?
I don't know honestly, I don't know a lot about him. But I think Eisenberg makes compelling character choices. What do you think? Do you know a lot about Zuckerberg?

I don't know much about him either. I was just thinking about how the film is based on Mezrich's book, The Accidental Billionaires. I just know that some of the facts presented in the text have been disputed.
I think it was important to the director to capture the themes/mood of the book rather than the facts. It would've been a boring movie otherwise.
That's a good point. I really think it was an exciting film, which I wouldn't expect for a movie about a social media startup.
What do you think about Andrew Garfield's work?

I think he seemed suited to the role of Saverin. Although I really knew little to nothing about the origins of Facebook before this film. Did you have any idea that Zuckerburg created that site to rate women's attractiveness?
I think that says a lot about the tech industry. Maybe that's why it's rated so high on Rotten Tomato and Metacritic
Why do you think the CinemaScore is lower?

Yeah. It's just insane that that's how Facebook got its start. I was really surprised by a lot of the things in this film. Honestly I don't know about the score though. It does seem strange that the rating on CinemaScore would be significantly lower than the other two.
Do you tend to care about movies' ratings before you watch them?
I follow a few different sites, and CinemaScore seems to be lower on a lot of movies. I only see a few movies a year so I always check the scores.
Do you care about movie ratings?
Not as much, I guess. I often feel like I disagree with the ratings of films. I feel that the critics' and my own opinions aligned with The Social Network, though.
It was a very popular movie. Biographics always are. Do you think The Social Network impacted American culture?
I'm not sure. I feel like the film really illustrated something that became a big part of American culture though. Do you feel like it had a big impact?
I think it did. Facebook is such an important part of the culture, and even if the movie wasn't factual it ended up being the narrative we all believe anyway.
I think it also showcased the beginning of the tech industry in California pretty well too, and that's a big issue nowadays

I agree with you about the film being the narrative people believe. I feel like most people who watched the film probably had no idea about a lot of the stuff concerning the creation of Facebook, myself included. So they see the film, and accept it as truth.
So I guess the question of truth comes down to if Zuckerberg liked it or not. It did make him look endearing as an anti-hero if anything

I thought it was effective that they cut in scenes from the lawsuits against Zuckerburg throughout the film. 
d
Yeah the use of time jumps can either go very well or very badly
Do you think this made you sympathetic/unsympathetic towards him?
I felt unsympathetic because it seemed like a lot of his problems came from himself, however the twins suing him was sympathtic
What do you think?

Yeah me too. I especially disliked him when he friend requested the ex girlfriend he'd slandered online initially He kept refreshing the page like expecting her to immediately accept. It seemed arrogant.
It came off as sad and desperate
Which made me pity him
